title: Is legal counsel at government expense available for pro se Appellants seeking to appeal to U.S. Supreme Court?
question: Is legal counsel at government expense available for self-represented bankrupt Appellant seeking to appeal (Writ of Certiorari, etc.) to U.S. Supreme Court on matters involving federal matters of law (i.e., denial of civil rights for due process and other rights) in a bankruptcy appeal?
answers: If your case is strong enough, you may get some support from organizations like the National Association of Consume Bankruptcy Attorneys. But if you lose at the Ninth Circuit, the likelihood of the Supreme Court granting cert is small.
No this is a civil matter and you’re not entitled to lawyer and government expense

Free legal representation is way down the list of your obstacles. The US Supreme Court only takes a very small percentage of the thousands of cases seeking consideration there. Sorry to rain on your parade.

You have to get past Supreme Court Rule 10
(A) United States court of appeals has entered a decision in confict with the decision of another United States court of appeals on the same important matter; has decided an important federal question in a way that conficts with a decision by a state court of last resort; or has so far departed from the accepted and usual course of judicial proceedings, or sanctioned such a de- parture by a lower court, as to call for an exercise of this Court’s supervisory power;
(b) a state court of last resort has decided an impor- tant federal question in a way that conficts with the decision of another state court of last resort or of a United States court of appeals;
(c) a state court or a United States court of appeals has decided an important question of federal law that has not been, but should be, settled by this Court, or has decided an important federal question in a way that conficts with relevant decisions of this Court.
